[[File:MichelineBernardini.jpg|thumb|right|225px|Since the [[bikini]] was introduced in 1946, it has generated a number of variations, primarily smaller and more revealing than the original.]]
+
[[File:MichelineBernardini.jpg|thumb|right|225px|Since the [[bikini]] was introduced in 1946, it has generated a number of variations, primarily smaller and more revealing than the original. {{deletable image-caption|Friday, 1 July 2011}}]]
The [[bikini]] has spawned many stylistic variations. A regular bikini is defined as a two pieces of garments that cover the groin and buttocks at the lower end and the breasts in the upper end. Some bikinis can offer a large amount of coverage, while other bikinis provide only the barest minimum. Topless variants may still be considered bikinis, although technically no longer two-piece swimsuits.<ref name=SStyle>[http://www.swimsuit-style.com/bikini-swimsuit.html Bikini], Swimsuit Styles</ref> Along with a variation in designs term bikini was followed by an often hilarious lexicon including the numokini (top part missing), seekini (transparent bikini), tankini (tank top, bikini bottom), camikini ([[camisole]] top and bikini bottom) and hikini.<ref name="Barry J. Blake page 59">Barry J. Blake, ''Playing with Words: Humour in the English Languageâ'', page 59, Equinox, 2007, ISBN 1-84553-330-5</ref> Since fashions of different centuries exist beside one another in early 21st century, though it is possible to imagine a woman combining a bikini and a 1910 bathing costume.<ref>Jacques Laurent & CÃ©cil Saint-Laurent, ''A History of Ladies Underwearâ'', page 214, Joseph, 1968, ISBN 0-7181-0624-5</ref>
The [[bikini]] has spawned many stylistic variations. A regular bikini is defined as a two pieces of garments that cover the groin and buttocks at the lower end and the breasts in the upper end. Some bikinis can offer a large amount of coverage, while other bikinis provide only the barest minimum. Topless variants may still be considered bikinis, although technically no longer two-piece swimsuits.<ref name=SStyle>[http://www.swimsuit-style.com/bikini-swimsuit.html Bikini], Swimsuit Styles</ref> Along with a variation in designs term bikini was followed by an often hilarious lexicon including the numokini (top part missing), seekini (transparent bikini), tankini (tank top, bikini bottom), camikini ([[camisole]] top and bikini bottom) and hikini.<ref name="Barry J. Blake page 59">Barry J. Blake, ''Playing with Words: Humour in the English Languageâ'', page 59, Equinox, 2007, ISBN 1-84553-330-5</ref> Since fashions of different centuries exist beside one another in early 21st century, though it is possible to imagine a woman combining a bikini and a 1910 bathing costume.<ref>Jacques Laurent & CÃ©cil Saint-Laurent, ''A History of Ladies Underwearâ'', page 214, Joseph, 1968, ISBN 0-7181-0624-5</ref>
